    Main Function for Fitting Fixed Effects Model

    logis_fe.Rd

    Main Function for Fitting Fixed Effects Model

    logis_fe(
  data.prep,
  algorithm = "SerBIN",
  max.iter = 10000,
  tol = 1e-05,
  bound = 10,
  backtrack = FALSE,
  Rcpp = TRUE,
  AUC = FALSE,
  message = FALSE
)

    Arguments

    data.prep

    an object from the `fe_data_prep()` function.

    algorithm

    a string specifying the algorithm to be used. Defaulting to "SerBIN". * `SerBIN`: using the Serial blockwise inversion Newton algorithm to fit the model (See reference: Wu et al.). * `BAN`: using the block ascent Newton algorithm to fit the model (See reference: He et al.).

    max.iter

    maximum number of iterations

    tol

    a small positive number specifying stopping criterion of Newton-Raphson algorithm

    bound

    a positive number to avoid inflation of provider effect. Default is 10.

    backtrack

    a boolean indicating whether backtracking line search is implemented, defaulting to FALSE

    Rcpp

    a Boolean indicating whether the Rcpp function is used, defaulting to TRUE

    AUC

    a Boolean indicating whether report AUC, defaulting to FALSE

    message

    a Boolean indicating whether track the fitting process

    ...

    Value

    An object with S3 class logis_fe.

    beta

    a vector of fixed effects estimates of covariates

    gamma

    a vector of estimates of facility effects

    obs

    a vector of patients-level outcome

    neg2Loglkd

    minus two times log likelihood

    AIC

    Akaike info criterion

    BIC

    Bayesian info criterion

    AUC

    area under the ROC curve

    Details

    The default algorithm is based on Serial blockwise inversion Newton (SerBIN) proposed by Wu et al. (2022), but users can also choose to use the block ascent Newton (BAN) algorithm proposed by He et al. (2013) to fit the model. We suggest using the default "SerBIN" option as it typically converges much faster for most datasets. However, in rare cases where the SerBIN algorithm encounters second-order derivative irreversibility leading to an error, users can consider using the "BAN" option as an alternative.

    References

    • Wu, W, Yang, Y, Kang, J, He, K. (2022) Improving large-scale estimation and inference for profiling health care providers. Statistics in Medicine, 41(15): 2840-2853.

    • He K, Kalbfleisch, J, Li, Y, and et al. (2013) Evaluating hospital readmission rates in dialysis facilities; adjusting for hospital effects. Lifetime Data Analysis, 19: 490-512.

    Examples

    data(data_FE)
data.prep <- fe_data_prep(data_FE$Y, data_FE$Z, data_FE$ID)
#> Checking missingness of variables ... 
#> Missing values NOT found. Checking missingness of variables completed!
#> Checking variation in covariates ... 
#> Checking variation in covariates completed!
#> Checking pairwise correlation among covariates ... 
#> Checking pairwise correlation among covariates completed!
#> Checking VIF of covariates ... 
#> Checking VIF of covariates completed!
#> Warning: 0 out of 10 providers considered small and filtered out!
#> 0 out of 10 remaining providers with no readmission within 30 days.
#> 0 out of 10 remaining providers with all readmissions within 30 days.
#> After screening, 52% of all discharges were readmitted within 30 days.
fit_fe <- logis_fe(data.prep, message = TRUE)
